hat's not the case. It may well be the case for some - text/plain

o mind - but the majority of widely used media types are

ough to accommodate non-breaking extensions (where
> their introduction doe=
sn't affect the meaning of the core content).

very well put! my rule of th=
umb is: if the content "makes sense" in the more generic type, use that one=
 and make the extension semantics as easy to detect as possible (and "profi=
le" is an attempt to provide such an easy way, reusable across media types)=
. if the content is pretty much incomprehensible (such as RDF/XML served as=
 application/xml), it provides little value (or even misleads clients) to e=
ven mention the more generic underlying media type. so far, it seems to me =
that this gives you a good starting point to decide how you want to satisfy=
 the "self-describing" constraint.

cheers,

dret.
